column4: why would 'synaptic' and 'apt-get' have such cumbersome and non-descriptive names?
it needs to be called something akin to what it does.
if 'synaptic' and 'apt-get' are the functional equivalent of the conventional 'Software Update', then 'Software Update' is the one I'd use when I think I might want to update my software.
thehatsrule - I can't go round doing that on everyone elses machines though
thehatsrule - there's little point in balkanising my own installation
the names of programs of open-source programs is a significant problem that needs attention.
it would seem that the people in charge of making open source programs are by and large, quite bad at conceiving viable names for the product.
or with the GPL, you can actually go out, rename every program you want to, and distribute it under the different names
but that really doesn't solve the problem, does it.
I'm not sure I see a problem, are there any specific examples?
well, the specific examples I've already related are 'synaptic' and 'apt-get'
compared to the conventional 'Software Update'
no, it's called 'apt-get', not 'advanced packaging tool-get'
it's an acronym
and who cares how advanced the packaging tool is - it should describe what it does
doesn't matter - who cares - if it's that advanced, it sorts it out for you
when I use Software Update, all I need to know is that it's found some updated software (or not) and it gets on and does it. I don't need to know how or why.
but they arn't the same, some are geared for speed, others for eyecandy, there are many differences between them
have you tried gnome-app-install?
no, never heard of it
it may be more to your liking, so you can at least recommend it to people
